Title: Phylogeny of Leavenworthia and Selenia (Brassicaceae)
Keywords:
Evolution, Leavenworthia, phylogeny, self-incompatibility,
Selenia, simultaneous analysis
Abstract:
The present study aimed to develop a robust, extensively
sampled phylogenetic hypothesis across all species in Leavenworthia and
Selenia using chloroplast (psbJ to petA) and nuclear encoded (nrDNA ITS
and LUMINIDEPENDENS) DNA sequence data. Parsimony and maximum likelihood
methodologies were employed. Strong ML bootstrap and parsimony jackknife
support were recovered for the monophyly of the sister pair
Leavenworthia plus Selenia and for the respective monophyly of each
genus. Leavenworthia and Selenia are hypothesizes to have originated in
the Ozark Mountains and results from an analysis of branch lengths
leading to Leavenworthia and Selenia are consistent with Leavenworthia
having diversified more recently than Selenia. Comparative results from
phylogenetic analyses indicate that L. aurea and L. texana are hybrids
with a shared set of putative parents. Polyploidy and extensive
aneuploidy complicate the interpretation of chromosomal evolution within
and between these genera. Lastly, patterns of diversification within
Leavenworthia have included a minimum of three transitions from
self-compatible to self-incompatible population systems.
